pull.title: test: Fix combine_logs.py for AppVeyor build
pull.body:
Fixes #16894

This fixes the problem of AppVeyor builds not showing `debug.log` if a functional test fails, because the windows separator `\` doesn't work together with the regex in `combine_logs.py`.

A fix was already attempted in  #16896, however, that PR became inactive and was marked "up for grabs", plus it's a really small change.

As suggested by jamesob, this PR uses `pathlib`: For the glob and to convert the path to a posix-style string, it leaves the regex as is (in contrast to #16896 which adjusted the regex).

I tested this locally on Windows and Ubuntu.

events.message: test: Fix combine_logs.py for AppVeyor build

events.body: Sorry, forgot about this. I thought it was already merged.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,10 +77,11 @@ def read_logs(tmp_dir):
     for each of the input log files."""
 
     # Find out what the folder is called that holds the debug.log file
-    chain = glob.glob("{}/node0/*/debug.log".format(tmp_dir))
-    if chain:
-        chain = chain[0]  # pick the first one if more than one chain was found (should never happen)
-        chain = re.search('node0/(.+?)/debug\.log$', chain).group(1)  # extract the chain name
+    chain = ''
comments.body:
Python doesn't have scope "blocks", so this is not needed. `chain` is in this functions' scope after assignment
```suggestion
```

@@ -78,10 +77,10 @@ def read_logs(tmp_dir):
     for each of the input log files."""
 
     # Find out what the folder is called that holds the debug.log file
-    chain = glob.glob("{}/node0/*/debug.log".format(tmp_dir))
-    if chain:
-        chain = chain[0]  # pick the first one if more than one chain was found (should never happen)
-        chain = re.search(r'node0/(.+?)/debug\.log$', chain).group(1)  # extract the chain name
+    # pick the first one if more than one chain was found (should never happen)
+    debugpath = next(pathlib.Path(tmp_dir).glob('node0/**/debug.log'),None)
+    if debugpath:
+        chain = re.search(r'node0/(.+?)/debug\.log$', debugpath.as_posix()).group(1)  # extract the chain name
comments.body:
nit,

```py
glob = pathlib.Path(tmp_dir).glob('node0/**/debug.log')
path = next(glob, None)
if path:
    assert next(glob, None) == None      # should never happen
    chain = ...
    ...
```

-    if chain:
-        chain = chain[0]  # pick the first one if more than one chain was found (should never happen)
comments.body: Nit, not critical here but if it should never happen I would throw an exception instead

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,10 +77,10 @@ def read_logs(tmp_dir):
     for each of the input log files."""
 
     # Find out what the folder is called that holds the debug.log file
-    chain = glob.glob("{}/node0/*/debug.log".format(tmp_dir))
-    if chain:
-        chain = chain[0]  # pick the first one if more than one chain was found (should never happen)
-        chain = re.search(r'node0/(.+?)/debug\.log$', chain).group(1)  # extract the chain name
+    # pick the first one if more than one chain was found (should never happen)
+    debugpath = next(pathlib.Path(tmp_dir).glob('node0/**/debug.log'),None)
+    if debugpath:
+        chain = re.search(r'node0/(.+?)/debug\.log$', debugpath.as_posix()).group(1)  # extract the chain name
comments.body: Done, that makes it a bit more readable. Also added assert.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,10 +77,11 @@ def read_logs(tmp_dir):
     for each of the input log files."""
 
     # Find out what the folder is called that holds the debug.log file
-    chain = glob.glob("{}/node0/*/debug.log".format(tmp_dir))
-    if chain:
-        chain = chain[0]  # pick the first one if more than one chain was found (should never happen)
-        chain = re.search(r'node0/(.+?)/debug\.log$', chain).group(1)  # extract the chain name

comments.body: Is this recursive on purpose or would `'node0/*/debug.log'` suffice?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,10 +77,11 @@ def read_logs(tmp_dir):
     for each of the input log files."""
 
     # Find out what the folder is called that holds the debug.log file
-    chain = glob.glob("{}/node0/*/debug.log".format(tmp_dir))
-    if chain:
-        chain = chain[0]  # pick the first one if more than one chain was found (should never happen)
-        chain = re.search(r'node0/(.+?)/debug\.log$', chain).group(1)  # extract the chain name
+    glob = pathlib.Path(tmp_dir).glob('node0/**/debug.log')
comments.body: Not on purpose. Non-recursive would suffice, I can't imagine a scenario where debug.log ends up in any subdirectories of node0.
